title: How to Make Your Feet Smell Good

steps.title: Soak your feet in water and baking soda.
steps.content: Soak your feet in water and baking soda. Sodium bicarbonate, commonly known as baking soda, is an effective remedy to eliminate foot odor as it neutralizes the pH of your sweat and reduces the amount of bacteria on your feet. Add baking soda in warm water (one tablespoon for every cup of water) in a tub or foot basin. Soak your feet for 15 to 20 minutes every night for about one week. To add a nice smell to the soak, squeeze the juice of one lemon into the baking soda and water. Make sure you dry your feet completely after the soak. [2] X Research source You can also sprinkle baking soda in your shoes and socks to fight any odors.

steps.title: Use black tea to get rid of smelly feet.
steps.content: Use black tea to get rid of smelly feet. [3] X Research source Pour several cups of very hot or boiling water into a tub or foot basin. Add 4 bags of black tea, or two tea bags per cup of water. Let the bags steep in the boiling water for 10 minutes. Then add a few cups of cool water to bring the temperature of the water down until it is comfortable for your feet. Soak your feet for 20 minutes. Do this once a day, making sure to thoroughly dry your feet after each soak.

steps.title: Try a vinegar soak.
steps.content: Try a vinegar soak. Vinegar does a good job of getting rid of odor and creates an acidic environment that may discourage the development of smelly bacteria. [4] X Research source Fill a tub or foot basin with 5-8 cups of warm water. Add ½ cup of white distilled or apple cider vinegar. Place your feet in the basin, swish the mixture around and let them soak for 15 minutes, twice a day. Make sure you clean and dry your feet completely when you finish soaking them by rinsing them in cold water and towel drying them.

steps.title: Use Epsom salts to reduce the sweat on your feet.
steps.content: Use Epsom salts to reduce the sweat on your feet. Epsom salt minimizes the bad odor on your feet as it fights microbial infection and neutralizes most odors. As an added bonus, it’s also great at soothing aching or sore feet. Mix two cups of Epsom salt into warm water in a foot basin or tub. Soak your feet for 15 minutes, twice a day. For the best results, do this soak before you go to sleep so you do not have to wear socks or shoes for a few hours.

steps.title: Apply lavender oil to your feet.
steps.content: Apply lavender oil to your feet. Lavender oil will make your feet smell good. [5] X Research source Before trying this remedy, always check to make sure the oil won’t irritate your skin by putting one drop on a small area of your body. If there is no reaction or itchiness after several minutes, use the oil. Rub a few drops of the oil onto your feet and massage it in right before you go to bed. You can also create a soak with lavender oil by putting a few drops of oil into warm water in a foot basin or a tub and soaking your feet for 15-20 minutes, twice a day.

steps.title: Try a sage and rosemary soak.
steps.content: Try a sage and rosemary soak. Sage is a bit of a wonder herb, as it is has antibacterial, antiviral and antifungal properties, and is also an astringent. Rosemary is also an astringent that has antibacterial and antifungal properties, which means both herbs help to minimize the production of sweat from your sweat glands. [6] X Research source Less sweat on your feet means a less ideal environment for smelly bacteria. Plus, these herbs will leave your feet smelling pleasant and feeling refreshed. Fill a tub or foot basin with several cups of boiling water. Add 1 teaspoon of dried rosemary and 1-2 teaspoons of dried sage to the water. Let the herbs steep until the water is cool enough to put your feet in, but still warm. Soak for 30 minutes, one to two times a day.

steps.title: Use Hibiscrub soap on your feet.
steps.content: Use Hibiscrub soap on your feet. This special antibacterial soap is very effective at killing the bacteria responsible for smelly feet. [7] X Research source You can purchase Hibiscrub soap online or at your local drugstore. Wash your feet with Hibiscrub soap in a tub or foot basin, and leave a lather of the soap on your feet for about 2 minutes before you wash it off. Apply the soap once in the morning and once before you go to bed. Your feet should smell pretty fresh within a week of using this soap.

steps.title: Buy a foot powder.
steps.content: Buy a foot powder. There are many commercially available foot powders, like Gold Bond and Dr. Scholl’s Odor X-Foot Powder [8] X Research source , which control foot odor and reduce any itchiness on your feet.

steps.title: Apply a spray deodorant or antiperspirant to your feet.
steps.content: Apply a spray deodorant or antiperspirant to your feet. A normal underarm deodorant can work just as well on your feet as a specialty foot product, at half the cost. [9] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Ask your doctor about prescription foot powders and ointments.
steps.content: Ask your doctor about prescription foot powders and ointments. They can prescribe stronger powders and ointments to fight foot odor, as well as stronger antiperspirants to fight excessive sweating, if over the counter options are not working.

steps.title: Consult with your doctor if you feel your level of sweating is abnormally high.
steps.content: Consult with your doctor if you feel your level of sweating is abnormally high. Your doctor could refer you for a treatment called iontophoresis, which delivers a mild electric current through water to your feet to combat excessive sweating. [10] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Wash your feet daily and dry them well.
steps.content: Wash your feet daily and dry them well. Use lukewarm water when you wash them and make sure you dry them well after every shower or bath. Moisture can encourage the growth of smelly bacteria. Don't be too aggressive while cleaning your feet, especially if you're using sharp tools. This can lead to cuts and other issues, like ingrown toenails. [11] X Expert Source Catherine Cheung, DPM Board Certified Podiatrist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020.

steps.title: Switch up your shoes so you aren’t wearing the same pair every day or several days in a row.
steps.content: Switch up your shoes so you aren’t wearing the same pair every day or several days in a row. Odors from your feet can linger in your shoes, so give your shoes at least 24 hours to air out. To help your shoes dry out faster, remove the inner soles in the shoes, if possible. [12] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Avoid wearing plastic shoes, as they will not let your feet breath. Instead, look for shoes made of leather, canvas, or sports mesh. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Change your socks once a day.
steps.content: Change your socks once a day. You should also only wear thick, soft socks made of an absorbent material like cotton or wool. Nylon socks are not very good at preventing smelly feet as they are not very breathable and may cause your feet to sweat. Look for feet-fresh socks, which are specifically made for people who play sports. They have ventilation panels to keep your feet dry. [14] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source You could also switch to antibacterial socks, which are covered in chemicals to discourage the growth of odor producing bacteria on your feet.

steps.title: Dust your feet frequently with non-medicated baby powder or foot powder.
steps.content: Dust your feet frequently with non-medicated baby powder or foot powder. This will help to sooth your feet, and prevent itchiness, and odor. [15] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Get medicated insoles for your shoes.
steps.content: Get medicated insoles for your shoes. These are insoles that are specially made to fight foot odor, as they keep your shoes smelling fresh when your feet are sweaty and they will also absorb some of the sweat.

steps.title: Wear sandals in the summer or during warm weather.
steps.content: Wear sandals in the summer or during warm weather. This will prevent your feet from sweating too much in your shoes and lessen the development of odor causing bacteria.

steps.title: Examine your feet for any infections and get them checked.
steps.content: Examine your feet for any infections and get them checked. Look between your toes and on the bottoms of your feet for any redness or dry, patchy skin. Get treatment for any fungal infections as soon as possible to prevent them from becoming a larger issue.<ref> https://health.clevelandclinic.org/4-sure-fire-ways-you-can-avoid-stinky-feet/ <ref>
